So the following case I want to consider. Let A,B,C be Types and f: A->B, g: A->C. B can be a canonical quotient, So let's say A=Z B=Z/5Z and C some arbitrary set. Assume that g respects the quotient. In my case g would be the map that sends 1 to a primitive 5-th root of a field K, which can be the complex numbers. Let S be a subset of A, in our case Z. I want to show that the image of S under both f and g have the same cardinality. Or that there exists a bijection between f(S) and g(s)

Here's how I came so far, but I am struggling to define the quotient. I have experimented a bit with the equivalence relations as Quotient.lift seems to depend on it.

import Mathlib

universe u

variable {α : Type}{β : Type}{γ : Type}

variable {f: α->β}
variable {g: α->γ}

def even_distance (a b : ℤ) : Prop := (a - b) % 4 = 0

instance ld : Setoid ℤ :=
{ r := even_distance,
  iseqv :=
  { refl := by simp [even_distance],
    symm := by
      intro h y
      intro s
      rw[even_distance] at s
      rw[even_distance]
      simp at s
      simp
      apply Dvd.dvd.neg_right at s
      simp at s
      assumption
    trans := by
      intro h y s d a
      rw[even_distance] at d a
      rw[even_distance]
      simp
      simp at d
      simp at a
      have c := Dvd.dvd.add d a
      simp at c
      assumption
  }
}


def quotient_map  : (Int -> Int) :=
  fun a => 2*a

def dd : (Int → Quotient ld) :=
  fun (a:ℤ ) => Quotient.mk ld a

def proj (z:Int) :=
  z%2

theorem quotient_injective_size_eq (A :Set α)  :
  Set.encard (Set.image f A) = Set.encard (Set.image g A) :=by
  sorry
Why do you believe this theorem to be true? Can you provide an informal proof?

Ok, here's something that I want to show. Consider a subset of integers A, let μ\muμ be an r-th primitive root of unity and consider the following two functions. f is the canonical quotient map into Z/rZ and g maps n to μn\mu^nμn. We observe that the preimage of g(1) is the residue class [0] mod r.

Let x be an element in the image of f. Then there exists a integer z such that f(z)=x, but g(z)=μzg(z)=\mu^zg(z)=μz, since μ\muμ is a primitive root of unity it is constant on equivalence classes. We can thus find a bijection between f(A) and g(A) by mapping each element from f(a) to the element g(a) and vice versa. Since we have a bijection between f(A) and g(A) we conclude that they have the same cardinality.
